FASTA.description:
FASTA files contain sequences of nucleotides or amino acids  
Example:
```
@FASTA_HEADER
ACACTCATACTGCTATGATACACTGACT
```

FASTQ.description:
FASTQ files contain sequences of nucleotides, but with added quality score from NGS sequencing  
Example:
```
@FASTQ_HEADER
CCCACTTATTCTACACCTCTCATGTCTCTTCACCGTGCCAGACTAGAGTC
+FASTQ_HEADER
AAAAAEEEEEEEEEAEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEAEEEEEEEEEEE
```
The header on the third line after the + symbol is optional, but the + symbol itself is not.

The fourth line of this format contains information about the quality of the read. Each symbol stands for a value which indicates the likelyhood that a base was read correctly. This value is known as the [Phred quality score](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phred_quality_score).

SAM.description: SAM files contain information on mapped and unmapped reads after alignment. SAM-files are plain-text files, as opposed to the binary-encoded BAM files. Because of this, SAM files are generally larger.

BAM.description: BAM files contain information on mapped and unmapped reads after alignment. BAN files contain the same information as SAM files, but are binary-encoded as opposed to plain-text. This encoding results in a smaller filesize.

edges.name: Direct
edges.description: FASTQ can be converted into FASTA by removing the quality header and quality score on every 3rd and 4th line.

edges.name: Alignment
edges.description: FASTQ files can be aligned on a reference genome using alignment tools such as Bowtie, STAR, BLAT and LAST

edges.name: Alignment
edges.description: FASTA files can be aligned on a reference genome using alignment tools such as Bowtie, STAR, BLAT and LAST

edges.name: SAMTools
edges.description: BAM files can be converted to SAM files using SAMTools

edges.name: SAMTools
edges.description: SAM files can be converted to BAM files using SAMTools
